title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act may be cited as the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". Definitions are provided in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as Corporation, Red Rock, Red Rock Map, and Secretary. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected and enhanced for future generations. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community, including 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock. The Corporation owns high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, intended for preservation. They propose the United States acquire the lands to protect and expand Red Rock through a land exchange. The Corporation proposes a land exchange with the United States to protect and expand Red Rock, in line with the Bureau of Land Management's plans and the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act. The Corporation proposes a land exchange with the United States to protect and expand Red Rock. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into the NCA. The Secretary will accept the offer and make conveyances of Federal lands to the Corporation and Clark County, Nevada as depicted on the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will convey private and Federal properties simultaneously. A map will be kept on file for public inspection. Conditions include the Corporation being responsible for hazardous materials removal and a survey requirement. The Secretary will require a metes and bounds survey of the common boundary between the parcels to be conveyed. The lands transferred to Clark County must be used only as a public park or part of a regional trail system in perpetuity. The lands transferred to Clark County must be used only as a public park or part of a regional trail system in perpetuity, and if the County attempts to transfer or use the lands inconsistently, they shall revert to the United States. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. The Secretary shall administer the lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as "Flood Control Detention Basin Lands" as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws upon enactment of this Act. Upon acquisition of lands, the Secretary shall administer them as part of Red Rock in compliance with specified Acts. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area is governed by various laws, including the Establishment Act of 1990 and the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998. New maps will be created to show the boundaries of Red Rock as modified by this Act. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to include additional areas in the conservation area. The general provisions of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area include creating new maps to show modified boundaries and making conforming amendments to include additional areas in the conservation area. The Secretary must review an appraisal and any difference in values must be reimbursed. The land exchange is subject to valid existing rights, and technical corrections to the Red Rock Map are allowed. (c) Technical Corrections.--Parties to conveyances under this Act can agree to correct technical errors or omissions in the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired or already owned by the United States within the Red Rock National Conservation Area boundaries. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on October 1, 2002.
